p: The observed antibacterial properties of the essential oils against various bacteria were different, ranging from strong antibacterial activity (inhibition zone > 20 mm) to moderate activity (inhibition zone < 12-20 mm) and even no inhibition (zone < 12 mm) (Orlanda and Nascimento 2015). Based on the width of the inhibition zone diameter, essential oils exhibits the strongest antibacterial activity against most Gram-positive organisms (except for E. faecalis) and a few Gram-negative organisms, including S. typhi, S. paratyphi and Salmonella enterica (p < 0.01). The weakest antibacterial activity was observed against P. aeruginosa, with a 10.40 ± 0.05 mm zone of inhibition (p<0.01).
